li: Java
Identify authentication functionality. Find the code that is responsible for authentication.

Verify that session IDs are changed during authentication. Review code responsible for logging in to make sure that code exists that clears the existing session state and creates a new session ID. For example:
        HttpSession session = request.getSession();session.invalidate();session = request.getSession(true);
IdentifyÂ authentication functionality. Find the code that is responsible for authentication.

Change session IDs during authentication. Add code that invalidates the current session ID and creates a new one. For example:
        HttpSession session = request.getSession();session.invalidate();session = request.getSession(true);

How to Test for Session Prediction Bugs in Java

html:
Applies to

  • Java

What to Check For

Verify that session IDs are changed during authentication.

Why

Change session IDs during authentication to make sure that the session state corresponds to the authenticated user.

How to Check

To verify that session IDs are changed during authentication:

  1. Identify authentication functionality. Find the code that is responsible for authentication.

  2. Verify that session IDs are changed during authentication. Review code responsible for logging in to make sure that code exists that clears the existing session state and creates a new session ID. For example:

    HttpSession session = request.getSession();
    session.invalidate();
    session = request.getSession(true);

How to Fix

To change session IDs during login:

  1. Identify authentication functionality. Find the code that is responsible for authentication.

  2. Change session IDs during authentication. Add code that invalidates the current session ID and creates a new one. For example:

    HttpSession session = request.getSession();
    session.invalidate();
    session = request.getSession(true);

Additional Resources

  • For more information about maintaining client state, please see http://download.oracle.com/javaee/1.4/tutorial/doc/Servlets11.html#wp64744

Java Session Management Guidelines

  • Use Session Management Offered by the Framework
  • Protect Session IDs
  • Protect Session Cookies
  • Set the Domain and Path Values of Session Cookies
  • Set the Secure and HTTPOnly Flags on All Sensitive Cookies
  • Change Session IDs During Authentication
  • Invalidate Sessions when Users Log Out
  • Make Inactive Sessions Time-out
  • Include Unique Tokens in HTTP Requests
  • Do Not Make Security Decisions Based on Client-Accessible Parameters

Java Session Management Checklists

  • Session Management Offered by the Framework Is Used
  • Session IDs Are Protected
  • Session Cookies are Protected
  • The Domain and Path Values of Session Cookies Are Strict
  • The Secure and HTTPOnly Flags Are Set on All Sensitive Cookies
  • Session IDs Are Changed During Authentication
  • Sessions Are Invalidated When Users Log Out
  • Inactive Sessions Time-out
  • Unique Tokens Are Included in HTTP Requests
  • Security Decisions are Not Made Based on Client-Accessible Parameters
